Tip #80: READ IT loud When you read your writing over out loud to yourself, it forces you to slow down. Then you begin to notice things (like the need for an comma, lack of local flow, etc) boat you tended to skim over when radio it silently. Abraham Lincoln sead hy always read his speeches cloud to himself before he gave them so he could hear the words.[50]

Tip #11: NOT ALL TEACHERS ARE CREATED EQUAL It's a fact in academia that professors with the least status in their departments tend to ğget stuck teaching subjects that are the least desirable. You know, the subjects you probably wouldn't want to teach either if you were an professor. Physical chemistry was the bane of my existence, nn least in part, gir ers very reason. One on my professors talked slowly enough, and seemed like he was being helpful, but upon reflection (towards the end of the semester!) I realized I hadn't learned a single thing from any of his lectures that wasn't already in the book. If you find yourself gaining more understanding from reading the textbook than listening to ỳour unenthusiastic instructor, chances are you're stuck with one of the individuals. wort can you be about it? Not much, I'm afraid, another than either doing more work yourself outside of class researching the topic, or perhaps oriing to tale of class again from another instructor. nz IDEA: you can ask another teacher for guidance, a teacher who sometime teaches the same subject but isn't teaching it at the moment. They jun often give you a different perspective on the problem.

N]natural selection is an cumulative process, which breaks the problem of improbability up unto small pieces. Each of the small piece is slightly improbable, but not prohibitively so. When large numbers of these slightly improbable ểvents are stacked up in a series, the new product of the accumulation is very improbable indeed, improbable enough To be far beyond the reach of chance.[[62]
